'''WNYF-LD:''' {{coord|44|29|29|N|74|51|27|W|type:landmark_scale:2000}}| homepage = | }} '''WNYF-CD''' is a [[Class A television service|Class A]] [[television station]] licensed to [[Watertown, New York]]. It broadcasts a [[High-definition television|high definition]] digital signal on [[UHF]] channel 35 ([[PSIP]] [[virtual channel]] 28) from a transmitter along State Street/[[New York State Route 126|NY 126]] in the [[Carthage, New York|Carthage]] section of [[Wilna, New York|Wilna]]. '''WNYF-LD''' is a [[low power television|low-powered]] television station licensed to [[Massena (village), New York|Massena]]. This broadcasts a digital signal on UHF channel 18 (PSIP virtual channel 28) from a transmitter southeast of South [[Colton, New York|Colton]] along [[New York State Route 56|NY 56]]. Together, the two serve as the [[North Country, New York|North Country]]'s [[Fox Network|Fox]] affiliates. The stations can also be seen on [[Time Warner Cable]] channel 2 and in high definition on digital channel 878. Owned by [[United Communications Corporation]], WNYF is sister to [[CBS]] affiliate [[WWNY-TV]] and the two share studios on Arcade Street in Downtown Watertown. [[television syndication|Syndicated]] programming on this station includes: ''[[My Name Is Earl]]'', ''[[Everybody Loves Raymond]]'', ''[[America's Funniest Home Videos]]'', and ''[[According to Jim]]''. WNYF can also be seen in Watertown on WWNY's second [[digital subchannel]] ([[VHF]] channel 7.2) from the Wilna tower. ==Digital programming== '''WNYF-CD 35 (Watertown - Champion Hill NY)''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Channel ! [[Video resolution|Video]] ! [[Aspect ratio|Aspect]] ! Programming |- | 28.1 || [[720p]] || [[16:9]] || main WNYF programming/Fox (HD) |} '''WNYF-LD 18 (Massena - South Colton NY)''' {| class="wikitable" |- ! Channel ! [[Video resolution|Video]] ! [[Aspect ratio|Aspect]] ! Programming |- | 28.1 || [[480i]] || [[16:9]] || main WNYF programming/Fox ([[standard definition|SD]]) |- | 28.2 || [[1080i]] || [[16:9]] || WWNY CBS (HD)[http://dtvtransition.blogspot.com/2010/10/wnyf-lp-now-on-air-digitally.html WNYF-LP Now on the Air Digitally], Mr James Corbin, WWNY/WNYF DTV Transition blog, Tuesday, October 5, 2010 |} ==History== Before becoming a separate entity, WNYF was a repeater for [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] affiliate [[WWTI]] with the call sign '''W28BC'''. During that time, WWTI and WWNY had secondary affiliations with Fox. WWNY's secondary affiliation was for [[National Football League]] games during the years CBS did not have broadcasting rights of the league. When that network acquired the rights to the [[American Football Conference]], WWTI then aired NFL from Fox, in addition to ABC's ''[[Monday Night Football]]'' (now on fellow [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] network [[ESPN]]). In 2001, United Communications Corporation and WWNY entered into an agreement with [[Smith Media, LLC|Smith Broadcasting]] to make W28BC and repeater station '''W25AB''' in Watertown separate full-time Fox affiliates. W28BC changed its call letters to '''WNYF-LP''' when the Watertown station changed its call letters to '''WNYF-CA''' signifying its upgrade to Class A status. WNYF-LP's low-powered analog signal on UHF channel 28 aired from a transmitter on [[New York State Route 420|NY 420]] in Massena. An agreement with [[Time Warner]] Cable in Fall 2001 placed the station on channel 2. After a year of joint operation of WNYF by Smith Broadcasting and United Communications, the latter took complete ownership and made it a full sister to WWNY. Until September 18, 2006 when [[UPN]] shut down and merged with [[The WB]] to form [[The CW]], WNYF also ran some programming from the network as a secondary affiliate. On August 25, 2008, WNYF-CA received [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) approval to begin its own high definition digital broadcasts as '''WNYF-CD''' on UHF channel 35 after WWNY-DT returned to its former analog position on VHF channel 7 (which happened February 17, 2009). On September 14, WNYF-CD signed-on using WWNY-DT's existing UHF antenna structure. The change represented the first time WNYF was available over-the-air in high definition. {{cite news |work=WWNY/WNYF DTV Transition |title=WNYF-CA, Watertown Makes the DTV/HDTV Transition |url=http://dtvtransition.blogspot.com/2009/09/wnyf-ca-watertown-making-dtvhdtv.html |date=2009-09-16}} On June 30, 2009, United Communications applied to the FCC for a digital version of WNYF-LP on UHF channel 18. This allocation was formerly used for [[WPBS-TV|WNPI-DT]]'s analog signal. It was approved for [[construction permit|construction]] on June 8, 2010. http://www.wwnytv.com/about/96043719.html Now known as '''WNYF-LD''', it features Fox as well as a simulcast of WWNY on a second digital subchannel. This helps [[St. Lawrence County, New York|St Lawrence County]] viewers who had experienced difficulty receiving WWNY's digital signal after that station transitioned to digital-only broadcasts. On December 16, 2010, WNYF began to be seen on Time Warner Cable systems in the [[Burlington, Vermont]]/[[Plattsburgh, New York]] market after the provider dropped that area's affiliate [[WFFF-TV]] because of an ongoing retransmission dispute. http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/2010/12/16/47829/denied-locals-twc-importing-distant-signals The dispute was eventually resolved and the home station was added back to the system. ==Newscasts== On April 11, 2001, WWNY began airing a 35 minute weeknight prime time broadcast at 10 on WNYF called ''7 News Tonight on Fox''. However, it was only seen by a handful of viewers able to receive that station's two low-powered over-the-air signals because WNYF was not yet being offered on cable. An agreement with Time Warner Cable in Fall 2001 placed the station on the system and the prime time news debuted for the rest of the area on October 4. WNYF simulcasts the 6 o'clock hour of WWNY's weekday morning news and then offers a second hour at 7 seen exclusively on this Fox affiliate while that station airs ''[[The Early Show]]''. The simulcast and separate show is known on WNYF as ''7 News This Morning on Fox''. Although there is no weekday morning or noon meteorologist, news anchor Beth Hall presents the weather forecast. During the weeknight weather segment, the station features a live [[National Weather Service]] [[weather radar]] based in the Parkers section of [[Montague, New York|Montague]]. ===News team=== '''Anchors''' *Jeff Cole - weekday morning news *Beth Hall - weekday morning news and weekday morning weather *Jeff Nelson - weeknight news and "Arts All-Star" segment producer *John Kubis - weeknight meteorologist *Mel Busler - weeknight sports and "Athlete of the Week" segment producer '''Reporters''' *Diane Rutherford - "Your Turn" and "Academic All-Star" segments producer *Craig Thornton - "Craig's To Do List" segment producer *Chris Manning - "TV Diner" segment producer *Art Ginsburg - "[[Mr. Food]]" segment producer *John Friot - St. Lawrence County *Jude Seymour - politics *Cindy Habeeb - health *Katie Alexander *Jessica Shaw *Sarah Compo *Stacy Lange *John Moore ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.wwnytv.net WNYF-CD/LD "Fox 28"] *{{TVQ|WNYF-CD}} *{{TVQ|WNYF-LD}} {{Watertown TV}} {{Syracuse TV}} {{Fox New York}} {{UCCorp}} [[Category:Fox network affiliates]] [[Category:Digital low-power stations]] [[Category:Channel 35 digital TV stations in the United States]] [[Category:Channel 18 digital TV stations in the United States]] [[Category:Channel 28 virtual TV stations in the United States]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2001]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2003]] [[Category:Television stations in New York]]
